speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have both the tools that we need and the resolve it will take to restore price stability on behalf of American families and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, the FOMC raised our policy interest rate by 75 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we continue to anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are moving our policy stance purposefully to a level that will be sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability will likely require maintaining a restrictive stance of policy for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will have more to say about today’s monetary policy actions after briefly reviewing economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy has slowed significantly from last year’s rapid pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Real GDP rose at a pace of 2.6 percent last quarter but is unchanged so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent indicators point to modest growth of spending and production this quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth in consumer spending has slowed from last year’s rapid pace, in part reflecting lower real disposable income and tighter financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Activity in the housing sector has weakened significantly, largely reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Higher interest rates and slower output growth also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite the slowdown in growth, the labor market remains extremely tight, with the unemployment rate at a 50-year low, job vacancies still very high, and wage growth elevated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: November 2, 2022 Job gains have been robust, with employment rising by an average of 289,000 jobs per month Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL over August and September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although job vacancies have moved below their highs and the pace of job gains has slowed from earlier in the year, the labor market continues to be out of balance, with demand substantially exceeding the supply of available workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor force participation rate is little changed since the beginning of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months ending in September, total PCE prices rose 6.2 percent; excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 5.1 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the recent inflation data again have come in higher than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price pressures remain evident across a broad range of goods and services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Russia’s war against Ukraine has boosted prices for energy and food and has created additional upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite elevated inflation, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that is not grounds for complacency; the longer the current bout of high inflation continues, the greater the chance that expectations of higher inflation will become entrenched.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship as it erodes purchasing power, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks that high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by 75 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet, which plays an important role in firming the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With today’s action, we have raised interest rates by 3¾ percentage points this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We anticipate that ongoing increases in the target range for the federal funds rate will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions have tightened significantly in response to our policy actions, and we are seeing the effects on demand in the most interest-rate-sensitive sectors of the economy, such as housing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take time, however, for the full effects of monetary restraint to be realized, especially on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s why we say in our statement that in determining the pace of future increases in the target range, we will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy and the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At some point—as I’ve said in the last two press conferences—it will become appropriate to slow the pace of increases as we approach the level of interest rates that will be sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is significant uncertainty around that level of interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, we still have some ways to go, and incoming data since our last meeting suggest that the ultimate level of interest rates will be higher than previously expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our decisions will depend on the totality of incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting and communicate our thinking as clearly as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are taking forceful steps to moderate demand so that it comes into better alignment with supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our overarching focus is using our tools to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keep longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reducing inflation November 2, 2022 is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth and some softening of labor market Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices in the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The historical record cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will stay the course until the job is done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I look forward to your questions.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Colby.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Colby Smith with the Financial Times.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: On the need to slow the pace of rate increases at some point: Is a downshift contingent on a string of better inflation data specifically between now and, let’s say, the December meeting?

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Or is that something that the Fed could potentially proceed with, independent of that data, given the lagged effects that you mentioned?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So a couple things on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do need to see inflation coming down decisively, and good evidence of that would be a series of down monthly readings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, that’s what we’d all love to see, but that’s—I’ve never thought of that as the appropriate test for slowing the pace of increases or for identifying the appropriately restrictive level that we’re aiming for.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We need to bring our policy stance down to a level that’s sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to our 2 percent objective over the medium term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: How will we know that we’ve reached that level?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, we’ll take into account the full range of analysis and data that bear on that question, guided by our assessment of how much financial conditions have tightened, the effects that that tightening is actually having on the real economy and on inflation, November 2, 2022 taking into consideration lags, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will be looking at real rates, for example, all Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL across the yield curve and all other financial conditions as we make that assessment.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Howard.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Hi, Howard Schneider with Reuters.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: I’m sure there’s going to be tons of confusion out there about whether this means you’re going to slow in December or not.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Would you say that the bias right now is not for another 75 basis point increase?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what I want to do is put that question of pace in the context of our broader tightening program, if I may, and talk about the statement language along the way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think you can think about our tightening program as really addressing three questions, the first of which was, and has been, how fast to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The second is how high to raise our policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the third will be, eventually, how long to remain at a restrictive level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So on the first question—how fast to tighten policy—it’s been very important that we move expeditiously, and we have clearly done so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve moved 3¾ percent since March, admittedly from a base of zero.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a historically fast pace, and that’s certainly appropriate given the persistence and strength in inflation and the low level from which we started.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So now we come to the second question, which is how high to raise our policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re saying that we’d raise that rate to a level that’s sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation to our 2 percent target over time, and we put that into our postmeeting statement because that really does become the important question, we think now, is how far to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll talk more about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think there’s some ground to cover before we meet that test, and that’s why we say that ongoing rate increases will be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, incoming data between the meetings, both a strong labor market report but particularly the CPI report, do suggest to me that November 2, 2022 we may ultimately move to higher levels than we thought at the time of the September meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL That level is very uncertain, though, and I would say we’re going to find it over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, with the lags between policy and economic activity, there’s a lot of uncertainty, so we note that in determining the pace of future increases, we’ll take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy as well as the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say, as we come closer to that level, move more into restrictive territory, the question of speed becomes less important than the second and third questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why I’ve said at the last two press conferences that at some point, it will become appropriate to slow the pace of increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that time is coming, and it may come as soon as the next meeting or the one after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No decision has been made.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is likely we’ll have a discussion about this at the next meeting, a discussion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To be clear, let me say again [that] the question of when to moderate the pace of increases is now much less important than the question of how high to raise rates and how long to keep monetary policy restricted, which really will be our principal focus.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: If I could follow up on that, to what degree was there an importance or weight given to a need to signal this possibility now, given all the concerns, really around the globe, about Fed policy sort of driving ahead and everybody else dealing with their own stress as a result?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think I’m pleased that we have moved as fast as we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think we’ve overtightened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there’s—very difficult to make a case that our current level is too tight, given that inflation still runs well above the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that at this meeting, as in the last two meetings, as I’ve mentioned, I’ve said that we—that there would come a point, and this was a meeting at which we had a discussion about what that might November 2, 2022 mean.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we did discuss this, and, as I mentioned, we’ll discuss it again in December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL there’s no—I don’t have any sense that we’ve overtightened or moved too fast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s been good and a successful program that we’ve gotten this far this fast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Remember, though, that we still think there’s a need for ongoing rate increases, and we have some ground left to cover here, and cover it we will.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nick.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Chair Powell, core PCE inflation on a 3- or 6-month annualized basis and on a 12-month basis has been running in the high 4s, close to 5 percent.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Is there any reason to think you won’t have to raise rates at least above that level to be confident that you are imparting enough restraint to bring inflation down?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is the question of, does the policy rate need to get above the inflation rate?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say, there are a range of views on it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the classic “Taylor principle” view.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would think you’d look more at a forward, a forward-looking measure of inflation to look at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think the answer is, we’ll want to get the policy rate to a level where it is, where the real interest rate is positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will want to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do not think of it as the single and only touchstone, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think you put some weight on that; you also put some weight on rates across the curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very few people borrow at the short end—at the federal funds rate, for example.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So households and businesses, if they’re [borrowing]—[there are] very meaningfully positive interest rates all across the curve for them, credit spreads are larger, so borrowing rates are significantly higher, and I think financial conditions have tightened quite a bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would look at that as an important feature.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d put some weight on it, but I wouldn’t say it’s something that is the single, dominant thing to look at.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: If I could follow up: What is your best assessment, or the staff’s best assessment right now, of the current rate of underlying inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t have a specific number for you there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are many, many models that look at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, I mean, one way to look at it is that it’s a pretty stationary object and that when inflation runs—above that level, for sure—substantially above for some time, you’ll see it move up, but the movement will be fairly gradual.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that’s what the principal models would tend to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I wouldn’t want to land on any one assessment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are many different—as you know, many different people publish an assessment of underlying inflation.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jeanna.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Thank you for taking our questions.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Jeanna Smialek with the New York Times.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: I wondered, do you see any evidence at this stage that inflation is, or is at risk of becoming, entrenched?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Is inflation becoming entrenched?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I would start by pointing to expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if we saw longer-term expectations moving up, that would be very troubling.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they were moving up a little bit at the middle part of this year, and they’ve moved now back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one piece of data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Shorter-term inflation expectations moved up between the last meeting and this meeting, and we don’t think those are as indicative, but they may be important in the wage-setting process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a school of thought that believes that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s very concerning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess the other thing I would say is that the longer we have—we’re now 18 months into this episode of high inflation, and we don’t have a clearly identified, scientific way of November 2, 2022 understanding at what point inflation becomes entrenched.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so the thing we need to do from Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL a risk-management standpoint is to use our tools forcefully but thoughtfully and get inflation under control—get it down to 2 percent—get it behind us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we really need to do and what we’re strongly committed to doing.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Rachel.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thank you for taking our questions.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Rachel Siegel from the Washington Post.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: The statement points to lag times.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: I’m wondering if you can walk us through how you judge those lag effects, what that timeline looks like over the coming months or even a year, and where you would expect it to show up in different parts of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the way I would think about that is, it’s commonly, for a long time, thought that monetary policy works with “long and variable lags,” and that it works first on financial conditions and then on economic activity and then perhaps later than that even on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s been the thinking for a long time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was an old literature that made those lags out to be fairly long.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s newer literature that says that they’re shorter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The truth is, we don’t have a lot of data [consisting] of inflation of [rates] this high in what is, now, the modern economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One big difference now is that it used to be that you would raise the federal funds rate, financial conditions would react, and then that would affect economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now financial conditions react well before in expectation of monetary policy [actions].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the way it has moved for a quarter of a century—in the direction of financial conditions, then monetary policy—because the markets are thinking, what is the central bank going to do?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there are plenty of economists that also think that once financial conditions change, that the effects on the economy are actually faster than they would have been before.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know November 2, 2022 that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess the thing that I would say is: It’s highly uncertain—highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so from Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL a risk-management standpoint—but we do need, it would be irresponsible not to, to ignore them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you want to consider them but not take them literally.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think it’s a very difficult place to be, but I would tend to be—want to be in the middle looking carefully at what’s actually happening with the economy and trying to make good decisions from a risk-management standpoint, remembering, of course, that if we were to overtighten, we could then use our tools strongly to support the economy, whereas if we don’t get inflation under control because we don’t tighten enough, now we’re in a situation where inflation will become entrenched and the costs, the employment costs in particular, will be much higher potentially.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So from a risk-management standpoint, we want to be sure that we don’t make the mistake of either failing to tighten enough or loosening policy too soon.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: And if I could follow up: Should we interpret the addition to the statement to mean that more weight is put into those lag effects than they would have been after previous rate hikes?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think as we move now into restrictive territory, as we make these ongoing rate hikes and policy becomes more restrictive, it’ll be appropriate now to be thinking more about lags.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we think about lags—the lags are just sort of a basic part of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we will be thinking about them, but we won’t be—I think we’ll be considering them but because it’s appropriate to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me say this: It is very premature to be thinking about pausing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So people, when they hear lags, they think about a pause.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s very premature, in my view, to think about or be talking about pausing our rate hike.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a ways to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our policy—we need ongoing rate hikes to get to that level of sufficiently restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t—of course, we don’t really know exactly where that is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a sense, and November 2, 2022 we’ll write down in September—sorry, in the December meeting, a new Summary of Economic Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL Projections, which updates that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would expect us to continue to update it based on what we’re seeing with incoming data.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Neil Irwin.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Thanks, Chair Powell.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Neil Irwin, Axios.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: As you look around the economy, the clearest impact of your tightening so far has been on housing, maybe some venture-funded tech companies.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: It’s been relatively narrow in terms of the labor market, consumer demand; a lot of sectors, you don’t see a ton of effect.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Is the pathway and channels through which monetary policy works changing?

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Is it narrower than it used to be?

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: And on housing in particular, are you at all worried that you’re cramping housing supply in ways that might cause problems down the road?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know that the channels through which policy works have changed that much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say a big channel is the labor market, and the labor market is very, very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And households, of course, have strong balance sheets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we go into this with a strong labor market and excess demand in the labor market, as you can see through many different things, and also with households who have strong spending power built up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it may take time, it may take resolve, it may take patience.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s likely to, to get inflation down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It may—I think you see, from our forecasts and others, that it will take some time for inflation to come down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll take time, we think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, sorry, was I getting to your question there?

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Housing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Oh, housing—the housing part of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, so we look at housing—of course, housing is significantly affected by these higher rates, which are really back where they were before the Global Financial Crisis—they’re not historically high, but they’re much higher November 2, 2022 than they’ve been.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re seeing housing activity decline, and you’re seeing housing prices Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL growing at a faster rate and, in some parts of the country, declining.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I would say housing was—the housing market was very overheated for the couple of years after the pandemic as demand increased and rates were low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We all know the stories of how overheated the housing market was, prices going up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many, many bidders and no conditions, that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the housing market needs to get back into a balance between supply and demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re well aware of what’s going on there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: From a financial stability standpoint, we didn’t see in this cycle the kinds of poor credit underwriting that we saw before the Global Financial Crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Housing credit was very carefully—much more carefully managed by the lenders.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a very different situation and doesn’t present potential financial—doesn’t appear to present financial stability issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, no, we do understand that that’s really where a very big effect of our policy is.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Victoria.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi, Victoria Guida with Politico.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: I wanted to ask about the labor market.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: You mentioned early on, again, that job openings are very high compared to available workers, and I’m just curious to what extent you do and don’t draw signal from that.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: So, for example, if wage growth is slowing and if maybe the unemployment rate starts to tick up, will that make you sort of decrease your focus on job openings?

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: What do you see—are wages what’s really important?

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: How are you thinking about the labor market as it relates to inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we talk a lot about vacancies in the—vacancy-to-unemployed rate, but it’s just one, it’s just another data series.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been unusually important in this cycle because it’s been so out of line.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But so has quits.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So have wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we look at a very wide range of data on the unemployment—on the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’d start with unemployment, November 2, 2022 which is typically the single statistic you would look to, is at a 50-year low, 3½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL getting really nothing in labor supply now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We had, I think, very small increase this year, which we had really thought, we thought we would get that back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Most analysts thought we would get some labor supply coming in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You mentioned wages, so I guess I would characterize that as sort of a mixed picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s true, with average hourly earnings, you see—so I would call it a flattening out at a level that’s well above the level that would be consistent over time with 2 percent inflation, assuming a reasonable productivity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With the ECI reading this week, again, a mixed picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The headline number was a disappointment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let’s just say it was high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It didn’t show a decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s some rays of light inside that if you look at private-sector workers—that did come down, that compensation did come down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, though, the broader picture is of an overheated labor market where demand substantially exceeds supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Job creation still exceeds sort of the level that would hold the market where it is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s the picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Do we see—we keep looking for signs that sort of the beginning of a gradual softening is happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And maybe that’s there, but it’s not obvious to me, because wages aren’t coming down—they’re just moving sideways at an elevated level, both ECI and average hourly earnings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to see—we would love to see vacancies coming down, quits coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They are coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Vacancies are below their all-time high but not by as much as we thought, because—and the data series is volatile, we never take any one reading, we always look at two or three.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a mixed picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t see the case for real softening just yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we look at, I guess as I just showed you, we look at a very broad range of data on the labor market.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: So do you see wages as being a significant driver of inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think wages have an effect on inflation and inflation has an effect on wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that’s always been the case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s always—going back and forth, the question is, is that really elevated right now?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think wages are the principal story of why prices are going up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also don’t think that we see a wage–price spiral, but, again, it’s not something you can—once you see it, you’re in trouble.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t want to see it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want wages to go up—we just want them to go up at a level that’s sustainable and consistent with 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think we can—we do think that, given the data that we have, that this labor market can soften without having to soften as much as history would indicate through the unemployment channel.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It can soften through job openings declining.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think there’s room for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we won’t know that—that’ll be, that’ll be discovered empirically.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: Thank you so much.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: Kayla Tausche from CNBC.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: Earlier last month, the United Nations warned that there could be a global recession if central banks didn’t change course.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: The new U.K. prime minister warned of a profound economic crisis there.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: And I’m wondering how the Fed is weighing international developments in light of a very strong economy here in the U.S. that would seem to be bucking those trends.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course, we, we keep close tabs on economic developments and also geopolitical developments that are relevant to the economy abroad.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re in very frequent contact with our foreign counterparts both through the IMF meetings and the regular meetings with central banks that we have, and I have one this weekend with many, many central bankers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re in touch with all of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess what—it’s clearly a time, a difficult time in the global economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re seeing very high inflation in Europe, significantly because of high energy prices related to the war in Ukraine.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re seeing China’s having issues with the November 2, 2022 zero-COVID policy and much slower growth than we’re used to seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re seeing—we Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL see those difficulties.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The strong dollar is a challenge for some countries.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we haven’t—we take all of that into account in our models.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think about the spillovers and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Here in the United States, we have a strong economy, and we have an economy where inflation is running at 5 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Core PCE inflation—which is a really good indicator of what’s going on for us, the way we see it—is running at 5.1 percent on a 12-month basis and sort of similar to that on a 3-, 6-, and 9-month basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we know that we need to use our tools to get inflation under control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The world’s not going to be better off if we fail to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a task we need to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability in the United States is a good thing for the global economy over a long period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the kind of thing that pays dividends for our economy—for decades, hopefully—even though it may be difficult to get it back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Getting it back is something that gives—that provides value to the people we serve for the long run.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: If I could just follow up up on that—thank you.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: The Fed has acknowledged in the past that the tools that you have don’t affect things like energy and food prices that stem from some of those conflicts overseas, and they’re some of the biggest pain points for consumers.

speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE
sentence: So as you pursue the current path that you’ve outlined, is there a risk that some of those prices simply don’t come down?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t directly affect, for the most part, food and energy prices, but the demand channel does affect them just at the margin.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The thing about the United States is that we also have strong—in many other jurisdictions, the principal problem really is energy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the United States, we also have a demand issue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve got an imbalance between demand and supply, which you see in many parts of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So our tools are well suited to work on that problem, and that’s what we’re doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t—the price of oil is November 2, 2022 set globally, and it’s not something we can affect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think by the actions that we take, though, we Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL help keep longer-term inflation expectations anchored and keep the public believing in 2 percent inflation by the things that we do, even in times when energy is part of the story of why inflation is high.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jonnelle.

speaker: JONNELLE MARTE
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: JONNELLE MARTE
sentence: Jonnelle Marte with Bloomberg.

speaker: JONNELLE MARTE
sentence: So the Fed is facing two more ethics-related incidents with the revision of the financial statements from President Bostic and President Bullard speaking at a closed event.

speaker: JONNELLE MARTE
sentence: So some senators, like Elizabeth Warren, are saying that this is a sign of greater ethics problems at the Fed.

speaker: JONNELLE MARTE
sentence: Could you talk about what this does to the public’s trust in the bank and what the Fed is doing to prevent this kind of behavior from becoming common?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re right—the public’s trust is really the Fed’s and any central bank’s most important asset, and any time one of us, one of the policymakers, violates or falls short of those rules, we do risk undermining that trust, and we take that very seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So at the beginning of our meeting yesterday, actually, we had a Committee discussion of the full Committee on the importance of holding ourselves individually and collectively accountable for knowing and following the high standard that’s set out in our existing rules with respect to both personal investment activities and external communications.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve taken a number of steps, and I would just say we do understand how important those issues are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say that our new investment program that we have is up now and running, and, actually, it was through that that the problems with President Bostic’s disclosures were discovered, when he filed his new disclosure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We now have a central group here at the Board of Governors that looks into disclosures and follows them and approves people’s disclosures and also all of their trades.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Any November 2, 2022 trade anyone has to make is covered, has to be approved, preapproved, and there’s a lag—it has Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL to be preapproved 45 days before it happens, so there’s no ability to game markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a really good system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It worked here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—I think we all said to each other today—yesterday, actually, yesterday morning, we recommitted to each other and to this institution to hold ourselves to the highest standards and avoid these problems.

speaker: JONNELLE MARTE
sentence: Do you have an update on the investigations that are pending?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you know, I referred the matter concerning President Bostic to the inspector general, and once that happens, I don’t discuss it with the inspector general or with anybody.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just—the inspector general has, he has the ability to do investigations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t really have that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what he’s doing.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Michael.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Michael McKee from Bloomberg Television and Radio.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Earlier this year, you touted the three-month bill yield out to 18 months as the yield curve with 100 percent explanatory power.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: And you said, quote, “If it’s inverted, that means the Fed’s going to cut, which means the economy is weak.” That curve is only 2 basis points away from inversion now, so I’m wondering why you are so confident that you have not overtightened, particularly given that rates work with a lag.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, so we do monitor the near-term forward spread—you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s—that’s been our preferred measure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think, just empirically, it dominates the ones that people tend to look at, which is 2s, 10s, and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s not inverted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, also, you have to look at why things—why the rate curve is doing what it’s doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It can be doing that because it affects—it expects cuts or because it expects inflation to come down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In this case, if you’re in a situation where the markets are pricing in significant declines in inflation, that’s November 2, 2022 going to affect the forward curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, yes, we monitor it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what I Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL would say.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: If I could follow up: You also said several meetings ago that the risk of doing too little outweighed the risk of doing too much.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Is what you’re trying to tell us today is that that risk assessment has changed a little bit?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, what’s happened is, time has passed, and we’ve raised interest rates by 375 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would not—I would not change a word in that statement, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think until we get inflation down, you’ll be hearing that from me.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, if we overtighten—and we don’t want to, we want to get this exactly right—but if we overtighten, then we have the ability with our tools, which are powerful, to, as we showed at the beginning of the pandemic episode, we can support economic activity strongly if that happens, if that’s necessary.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: On the other hand, if you make the mistake in the other direction and you let this drag on, then it’s a year or two down the road, and you’re realizing, inflation behaving the way it can, you’re realizing you didn’t actually get it, you have to go back in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: By then, the risk, really, is that it has become entrenched in people’s thinking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the record is that the employment costs—the cost to the people that we don’t want to hurt—they go up with the passage of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s really how I look at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that isn’t going to change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What has changed, though—you’re right—is, we’re farther along now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think as we’re farther along, we’re now focused on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What’s the place, what’s the level we need to get to rates?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I don’t know what we’ll do when we get there, by the way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It doesn’t—we’ll have to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s been no decision or discussion around exactly what steps we would take at that point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the first thing is to find your way there.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Chris Rugaber.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Chris Rugaber at Associated Press.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Just to go back to housing for a minute: You mentioned the impact that rate increases have had on housing—home sales are down 25 percent in the past year, and so forth—but none of this is really showing up in, as you know, in the government’s inflation measures.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: And as we go forward, private real-time data is clearly showing these hits to housing.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Are you going to need to put a greater weight on that in order to ascertain things like whether there’s overtightening going on, or will you still focus as much on the more lagging government indicators?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is an interesting subject.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I start by saying, I guess, that the measure that’s in the CPI and the PCE, it captures rents for all tenants, not just new leases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that makes sense, actually, because for that reason—conceptually, that is—that’s sort of the right target for monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the same thing is true for owners’ equivalent rent, which comes off of—it’s a reweighting of tenant rents.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The private measures are, of course, good at picking up, at the margin, the new leases, and they tell you a couple things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One thing is, I think right now, if you look at the pattern of that series of the new leases, it’s very pro-cyclical, so rents went up much more than the CPI and PCE rents did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now they’re coming down faster.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what you’re—the implication is that there are still, as people, as non-new leases roll over and expire, right, they’re still in the pipeline, there’s still some significant rate increases coming, okay?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But at some point, once you get through that, the new leases are going to tell you—what they’re telling you is, there will come a point at which rent inflation will start to come down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that point is well out from where we are now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re well aware of that, of course, and we look at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say that in terms of—the right way to think about inflation, really, is to look at the measure that we do look at, but considering that we also know that at some point, you’ll see rents coming down.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Great, and just a quick follow.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: It looks like stock and bond markets are reacting positively to your announcement so far.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Is that something you wanted to see?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Is that a problem or what—how that might affect your future policy to see this positive reaction?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not targeting any one or two particular things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our message should be—what I’m trying to do is make sure that our message is clear, which is that we think we have a ways to go, we have some ground to cover with interest rates before we get to, before we get to that level of interest rates that we think is sufficiently restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And putting that in the statement and identifying that as a goal is an important step.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s meant to put that question, really, as the important one now, going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve also said that we think that the level of rates that we estimated in September—the incoming data suggests that that’s actually going to be higher, and that’s been the pattern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I would have little confidence that the forecast—if we made a forecast today, if we were doing an SEP today, the pattern has been that, one after another, they go up, and that’ll end when it ends, but there’s no sense that inflation is coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the—I have a table of the last 12 months of 12-month readings, and there’s really no pattern there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re exactly where we were a year ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would also say, it’s premature to discuss pausing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s not something that we’re thinking about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s really not a conversation to be had now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a ways to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the last thing I’ll say is that I would want people to understand our commitment to getting this done and to not making the mistake of not doing enough or the mistake of withdrawing our strong policy and doing that too soon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those—I control those messages, and that’s my job.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Edward.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Edward Lawrence with Fox Business.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Thank you, Fed Chairman.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So how big of a headwind is all the fiscal spending to what the Federal Reserve’s trying to do to get inflation back to the 2 percent target?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In theory, it was a headwind this year, but I do think the broader context is that you have households that have these significant amounts of savings and can keep spending even in—so I think those two things do tend to wage—to sort of counterbalance each other out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It appears, consumer spending is still positive—it’s at pretty modest growth levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not shrinking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The banks that deal with retail customers and many retailers will tell you that the consumers are still buying and they’re still—they’re fine.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t know how big the fiscal headwinds are, and they haven’t shown up in the way that we thought they would in restraining spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it must have to do with the savings that people have.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So, what about the spending?

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: There’s tens of billions yet to be spent, I mean, from the Inflation Reduction Act, the American Rescue Plan, CHIPS Act, bipartisan infrastructure bill.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: How does that play into your thinking about the future?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Demand is going to have some support from those savings and also from the strong demand that’s still in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We still see pretty significant demand and a tightening labor market in some respects, although I think, overall, I would say it’s not really tightening or loosening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we see those things, and what those things tell us is that our job is going to require some resolve and some patience over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to have to stick with this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s just—we take all that as a given, but we know what our objective is, and we know what our tools can do, and that’s how we think about it.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Nancy for the last question.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer from Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: I’m wondering, has the window for a soft landing narrowed?

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Do you still think it’s possible?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Has it narrowed?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Is it still possible?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve always said it was going to be difficult, but I think to the extent rates have to go higher and stay higher for longer, it becomes harder to see the path—it’s narrowed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say the path has narrowed over the course of the last year, really.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Hard to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Hard to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, I would say that the sort of array of data in the labor market is highly unusual and, to many economists, there is a path to—ordinarily there’s a relationship to GDP going down and vacancies declining, translating into unemployment, or there’s Okun’s law.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So all those things are relationships that are in the data, and they’re very real.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Data’s a little bit different this time, though, because you have this tremendously high level of vacancies and, we think, on a very steep part of the Beveridge curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All I would say is that the job losses may turn out to be less than would be indicated by those traditional measures, because job openings are so elevated and because the labor market is so strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, that’s going to be something we discover empirically.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think no one knows whether there’s going to be a recession or not and, if so, how bad that recession would be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And our job is to restore price stability so that we can have a strong labor market that benefits all over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we’re going to do.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Just real quickly—why do you feel like the window has narrowed?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Because we haven’t seen inflation coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The implication of inflation not coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we would expect by now to have seen is that as the—really, as the supply-side problems have resolved themselves, we would have expected goods inflation to November 2, 2022 come down by now, long since by now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it really hasn’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Actually, it has come down, but Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL not to the extent that we had hoped.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the same time, now you see services inflation, core services inflation moving up, and I just think that the inflation picture has become more and more challenging over the course of this year, without question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That means that we have to have policy be more restrictive, and that narrows the path to a soft landing, I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
